GroveDB is the first database to support cryptographic proofs for complex queries

Store and retrieve data with absolute confidence.

GroveDB Features

Broad

Trustless

All query results can be cryptographically proven

Efficient

Proofs are efficient in terms of both size and time

Comprehensive

Support for secondary indexes and complex queries

Broad

Complex query proofs

Proofs for much more than just simple gets

Non-inclusion proofs

Verify the absence of items as well as their presence

Combinable tree types

Different tree types, such as sum trees, can be used within the same graph

Chunking

Quickly and trustlessly replicate state from one node to another

Operation costs

Get the cost for operations in terms of storage and computation

Secondary Indexes

What are secondary indexes?

Cryptographic Proofs

What are cryptographic proofs?

Design

How is GroveDB’s design unique?

GroveDB is the first production-level implementation of a hierarchical authenticated data structure (HADS), largely inspired by Database Outsourcing with Hierarchical Authenticated Data Structures.

HADS

What is a HADS?

In GroveDB, additional subtrees are automatically created for secondary indexes, and each secondary index subtree has additional subtrees for each unique value, creating a hierarchy of trees and items.

This architecture combined with Merk allows for cryptographic proofs to be provided with secondary index query results efficiently.

For example, say there is a “Restaurants Who Accept Dash” contract with a “Restaurants” document type. One of the secondary indexes for this document type might be “City”, which indicates which city the restaurant is located in.

This “City” secondary index would have its own subtree which stores all of the city names for which there are restaurants in the contract. Each city would then have its own subtree, containing the restaurants in that city.

Benefits of a HADS

Efficient proof generation for complex queries

Efficient handling of duplicate values

Support for compound indexes

Multiple tree types may be used in the same “grove”

Note that the secondary index subtrees contain references to items rather than the items themselves in order to save on storage space.

Merk

What is Merk?

By default, all trees in GroveDB are Merk trees.

Merk is a Merkle AVL tree designed for performance. Notable features include concurrent operations for higher throughput, an optimized key/value layout for performant usage of the backing store, and efficient proof generation to enable bulk tree replication.

Read Documentation
Features of the Merk trees
Fast reads/writes

Reads have no overhead compared to a normal RocksDB store, and writes are optimized for batch operations (e.g. blocks in a blockchain).

Fast proof generation

Since Merk implements an AVL tree rather than a trie, it is very efficient to create and verify proofs for ranges of keys.

Concurrency

Unlike most other Merkle stores, all operations utilize all available cores, giving huge performance gains and allowing nodes to scale along with Moore's Law.

Replication

The tree is optimized to efficiently build proofs of large chunks, allowing for nodes to download the entire state (e.g. "state syncing").

Checkpointing

Merk can create checkpoints on disk (an immutable view of the entire store at a certain point in time) without blocking, so there are no delays in availability or liveness.

Web-friendly

Being written in Rust means it is easy to run the proof-verification code in browsers with WebAssembly, allowing for light-clients that can verify data for themselves.

Fits any Profile

Performant on RAM-constrained Raspberry Pi's and beefy validator rigs alike.
